getMu

friction coefficient
See Also:
setMu(float)

setMu

public void setMu(float mu)
Coulomb friction coefficient. This must be in the range 0 to Float.POSITIVE_INFINITY. 0 results in a frictionless contact, and infinity results in a contact that never slips. Note that frictionless contacts are less time consuming to compute than ones with friction, and infinite friction contacts can be cheaper than contacts with finite friction. Friction must always be set.

Parameters:
mu - friction coefficient

getMuOrthogonal

public float getMuOrthogonal()
Specified by:
getMuOrthogonal in interface ContactHandlingDetails
Returns:
othogonal friction coefficient
See Also:
setMuOrthogonal(float)

setMuOrthogonal

public void setMuOrthogonal(float muOrthogonal)
Optional Coulomb friction coefficient for orthogonal friction direction (0..Infinity). The direction for this coefficient is orthogonal to the friction direction and the contact normal.

Parameters:
muOrthogonal - othogonal friction coefficient

getBounce

public float getBounce()
Specified by:
getBounce in interface ContactHandlingDetails
Returns:
bounce parameter
See Also:
setBounce(float)

setBounce

public void setBounce(float bounce)
Restitution parameter (0..1). 0 means the surfaces are not bouncy at all, 1 is maximum bouncyness.

Parameters:
bounce - bouncyness

getMinimumBounceVelocity

public float getMinimumBounceVelocity()
Specified by:
getMinimumBounceVelocity in interface ContactHandlingDetails
Returns:
minimum bounce velocity
See Also:
setMinimumBounceVelocity(float)

setMinimumBounceVelocity

public void setMinimumBounceVelocity(float minimumBounceVelocity)
The minimum incoming velocity necessary for bounce (in m/s). Incoming velocities below this will effectively have a bounce parameter of 0.

Parameters:
minimumBounceVelocity - new value

setSurfaceMotion

public void setSurfaceMotion(com.jme.math.Vector2f motion)
Surface velocity - if set, the contact surface is assumed to be moving independently of the motion of the nodes. This is kind of like a conveyor belt running over the surface. The x component of the vector specifies motion in friction direction and the y component specifies motion in direction orthogonal to friction direction and normal.

Parameters:
motion - new value, (0, 0) for no motion (not NaN)

getSurfaceMotion

setSlip

public void setSlip(com.jme.math.Vector2f slip)
The coefficients of force-dependent-slip (FDS). The x component of the vector specifies motion in friction direction and the y component specifies motion in direction orthogonal to friction direction and normal.
